articles.headline: Why Apple Scrapped the Release of Its Oscar Contender, ‘The Banker’
articles.snippet: A fact-based story starring Samuel L. Jackson and Anthony Mackie was supposed to hit theaters Friday. Then a complaint by a relative of the film’s hero gave Apple second thoughts.
articles.abstract: A fact-based story starring Samuel L. Jackson and Anthony Mackie was supposed to hit theaters Friday. Then a complaint by a relative of the film’s hero gave Apple second thoughts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple has struggled to find its footing as it tries to go Hollywood. Critics were lukewarm at best about “The Morning Show,” the star-studded, big-budget flagship series on Apple TV Plus, the streaming platform that went live Nov. 1. And now one of Apple’s first films, “The Banker,” starring Samuel L. Jackson and Anthony Mackie, is in limbo after the company pulled it from a theatrical run that was scheduled to start Friday.
articles.byline: By Nicole Sperling

articles.headline: How Aramco’s Huge I.P.O. Fell Short of Saudi Prince’s Wish
articles.snippet: As investors balked, some bankers and Saudi officials still hoped to achieve the crown prince’s target price of $2 trillion. They wound up settling for less.
articles.abstract: As investors balked, some bankers and Saudi officials still hoped to achieve the crown prince’s target price of $2 trillion. They wound up settling for less.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early on Oct. 15, a group of international investment bankers delivered some unwelcome news to top executives of Saudi Arabia’s giant oil company, Saudi Aramco.
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly and Stanley Reed

articles.headline: White House Signals Trump Won’t Mount House Impeachment Defense
articles.snippet: In a sharply worded letter, the White House counsel denounced the impeachment inquiry and called on Democrats to end it, or get it over with quickly so it could proceed to a Senate trial.
articles.abstract: In a sharply worded letter, the White House counsel denounced the impeachment inquiry and called on Democrats to end it, or get it over with quickly so it could proceed to a Senate trial.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House signaled on Friday that it did not intend to mount a defense of President Trump or otherwise participate in the House impeachment proceedings, sending Democrats a sharply worded letter that condemned the process as “completely baseless” and urged them to get it over with quickly.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: After 10 Years of Hopes and Setbacks, What Happened to the Common Core?
articles.snippet: It was one of the most ambitious education efforts in United States history. Did it fail? Or does it just need more time to succeed?
articles.abstract: It was one of the most ambitious education efforts in United States history. Did it fail? Or does it just need more time to succeed?
articles.lead_paragraph: The plan was hatched with high hopes and missionary zeal: For the first time in its history, the United States would come together to create consistent, rigorous education standards and stop letting so many school children fall behind academically.
articles.byline: By Dana Goldstein

articles.headline: With Impeachment Unfolding Amid a Booming Economy, What Will Voters Prioritize?
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump could find himself in 2020 presiding over a record-long economic expansion while defending his fitness to hold office.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump could find himself in 2020 presiding over a record-long economic expansion while defending his fitness to hold office.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump was greeted Friday morning with news of a blockbuster jobs report, showing that employers added 266,000 jobs in November and the unemployment rate fell to 3.5 percent, its lowest level since 1969.
articles.byline: By Annie Karni and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: Six Saudis Said to Be Questioned After Pensacola Navy Base Shooting
articles.snippet: Authorities were trying to determine whether the shooting that killed three and injured eight others was an act of terrorism.
articles.abstract: Authorities were trying to determine whether the shooting that killed three and injured eight others was an act of terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: PENSACOLA, Fla. — A member of the Saudi Air Force armed with a handgun fatally shot three people and injured eight others on Friday morning during a bloody rampage in a classroom building at the prestigious Naval Air Station in Pensacola, Fla., where he was training to become a pilot.
articles.byline: By Kalyn Wolfe, Patricia Mazzei, Eric Schmitt and Christine Hauser

articles.headline: PG&E Reaches $13.5 Billion Deal With Wildfire Victims
articles.snippet: The agreement could help tens of thousands of residents rebuild while helping to resolve the utility’s bankruptcy.
articles.abstract: The agreement could help tens of thousands of residents rebuild while helping to resolve the utility’s bankruptcy.
articles.lead_paragraph: After months of tense negotiations, Pacific Gas & Electric and lawyers for victims of wildfires that killed dozens of people and destroyed tens of thousands of homes and businesses agreed on Friday to a multibillion-dollar legal settlement.
articles.byline: By Ivan Penn, Lauren Hepler and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Splintered Isle: A Journey Through Brexit Britain
articles.snippet: As Britain heads for an election, a Times reporter spent two weeks driving from London to Glasgow. He found a country united only by its disunity.
articles.abstract: As Britain heads for an election, a Times reporter spent two weeks driving from London to Glasgow. He found a country united only by its disunity.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHIREBROOK, England — There used to be a mine at the edge of this small town near the center of England. Now there is only a warehouse.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Laetitia Vancon

articles.headline: Can Biology Class Reduce Racism?
articles.snippet: When it comes to race, “It’s always like ‘O.K., but now we’re going to start the lesson on peas,’’’ a biology teacher said. A study will test a new approach.
articles.abstract: When it comes to race, “It’s always like ‘O.K., but now we’re going to start the lesson on peas,’’’ a biology teacher said. A study will test a new approach.
articles.lead_paragraph: Please sign up here to have the Race/Related newsletter delivered weekly to your inbox.
articles.byline: By Amy Harmon

articles.headline: As Candidates Jostle for Position, a Long Race May Become a Marathon
articles.snippet: In a volatile primary with no true front-runner, Democrats face the prospect of a monthslong delegate battle that would also feature a lengthy public airing of the party’s ideological fissures.
articles.abstract: In a volatile primary with no true front-runner, Democrats face the prospect of a monthslong delegate battle that would also feature a lengthy public airing of the party’s ideological fissures.
articles.lead_paragraph: MASON CITY, Iowa — With just under two months until the Iowa caucuses, the already-volatile Democratic presidential race has grown even more unsettled, setting the stage for a marathon nominating contest between the party’s moderate and liberal factions.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Video Games and Online Chats Are ‘Hunting Grounds’ for Sexual Predators
articles.snippet: Criminals are making virtual connections with children through gaming and social media platforms. One popular site warns visitors, “Please be careful.”
articles.abstract: Criminals are making virtual connections with children through gaming and social media platforms. One popular site warns visitors, “Please be careful.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Criminals are making virtual connections with children through gaming and social media platforms. One popular site warns visitors, “Please be careful.”
articles.byline: By Nellie Bowles and Michael H. Keller

articles.headline: Before Florida Shooting, Gunman Showed Off Videos of Mass Attacks
articles.snippet: Investigators are still trying to understand the motive of a Saudi trainee who fatally shot three people at Naval Air Station Pensacola.
articles.abstract: Investigators are still trying to understand the motive of a Saudi trainee who fatally shot three people at Naval Air Station Pensacola.
articles.lead_paragraph: PENSACOLA, Fla. — As federal authorities worked on Saturday to piece together clues to last week’s attack at a Florida military training base, new details emerged about the gunman, a Saudi trainee who had apparently shown videos of mass shootings at a dinner party the night before.
articles.byline: By Frances Robles, Eric Schmitt, Patricia Mazzei and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

articles.headline: At Japan’s Most Elite University, Just 1 in 5 Students Is a Woman
articles.snippet: Enrollment of women at the University of Tokyo has remained about 20 percent for years, an imbalance that extends across many top Japanese colleges.
articles.abstract: Enrollment of women at the University of Tokyo has remained about 20 percent for years, an imbalance that extends across many top Japanese colleges.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — From a young age, Satomi Hayashi studied hard and excelled academically. It seemed only natural that she would follow in her father’s footsteps and attend the University of Tokyo, Japan’s most prestigious institution.
articles.byline: By Motoko Rich

articles.headline: A Farewell to Feministing and the Heyday of Feminist Blogging
articles.snippet: Another site is about to close, joining other publications like The Hairpin and The Toast that are dead or dying, as their “rowdy” voices go mainstream.
articles.abstract: Another site is about to close, joining other publications like The Hairpin and The Toast that are dead or dying, as their “rowdy” voices go mainstream.
articles.lead_paragraph: Soon after Anna Holmes took on the job of building the website Jezebel, in 2007, she set it apart from established publications like Vogue and Elle with a post offering $10,000 to anyone who would send in the best unretouched version of a women’s magazine cover photo. And with that, Jezebel had marked its territory: feminist cultural criticism, with an edge.
articles.byline: By Emma Goldberg

articles.headline: This Man May Be Big Tech’s Biggest Threat
articles.snippet: Representative David Cicilline doesn’t just want to enforce the laws governing the tech industry. He wants to change them.
articles.abstract: Representative David Cicilline doesn’t just want to enforce the laws governing the tech industry. He wants to change them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a hearing this summer about the rising power of the country’s biggest tech companies, Representative David Cicilline zeroed in on Amazon. Unhappy with a response from one of the company’s top lawyers, he delivered a biting retort.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr

articles.headline: Trump Cripples W.T.O. as Trade War Rages
articles.snippet: A U.S. offensive against the World Trade Organization will effectively shutter the group’s system for settling disputes, at a time it’s most needed.
articles.abstract: A U.S. offensive against the World Trade Organization will effectively shutter the group’s system for settling disputes, at a time it’s most needed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States has spent two years chipping away at the World Trade Organization, criticizing it as unfair, starving it of personnel and disregarding its authority, as President Trump seeks to upend the global trade system.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson

articles.headline: Barr Dives Into the Culture Wars, and Social Conservatives Rejoice
articles.snippet: The attorney general embodies the combative culture and conservative ideology that animate the president and the Republican Party. Is he what the party looks like post-Trump?
articles.abstract: The attorney general embodies the combative culture and conservative ideology that animate the president and the Republican Party. Is he what the party looks like post-Trump?
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump nominated William P. Barr as attorney general a year ago, establishment Republicans who had chafed at Mr. Trump’s takeover of their party were relieved. Between Mr. Barr’s work in the Reagan White House and his fast-track career under George Bush, he could be a bridge to the Republican Party they knew — and preferred.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Katie Benner

articles.headline: The Indispensable Man: How Giuliani Led Trump to the Brink of Impeachment
articles.snippet: Rudy Giuliani didn’t get the job he expected. But as unpaid personal counsel to the president and for-profit peddler of access and advice, he got the spotlight.
articles.abstract: Rudy Giuliani didn’t get the job he expected. But as unpaid personal counsel to the president and for-profit peddler of access and advice, he got the spotlight.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not so long ago, it seemed to Rudolph W. Giuliani that he would be presiding over a hefty part of the world.
articles.byline: By Jim Dwyer, Jo Becker, Kenneth P. Vogel, Maggie Haberman and Sarah Maslin Nir

articles.headline: Pensacola Attack Probed for Terrorism Link. Saudi Suspect Clashed With Instructor.
articles.snippet: The F.B.I. said it was conducting a terrorism investigation into the shooting at Naval Air Station Pensacola, as new information emerged about the gunman’s training at the facility.
articles.abstract: The F.B.I. said it was conducting a terrorism investigation into the shooting at Naval Air Station Pensacola, as new information emerged about the gunman’s training at the facility.
articles.lead_paragraph: The investigation into the fatal shooting last week at a Navy training center in Florida was officially characterized as a terrorism inquiry on Sunday, as new details emerged about the Saudi Air Force trainee who killed three sailors on the base where he was a visiting student.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

articles.headline: A Few Cities Have Cornered Innovation Jobs. Can That Be Changed?
articles.snippet: A new report documents the concentration of cutting-edge industries in a few coastal areas and why lawmakers ought to be alarmed.
articles.abstract: A new report documents the concentration of cutting-edge industries in a few coastal areas and why lawmakers ought to be alarmed.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are about a dozen industries at the frontier of innovation. They include software and pharmaceuticals, semiconductors and data processing. Most of their workers have science or tech degrees. They invest heavily in research and development. While they account for only 3 percent of all jobs, they account for 6 percent of the country’s economic output.
articles.byline: By Eduardo Porter

articles.headline: Documents Reveal U.S. Officials Misled Public on War in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: The documents, obtained by The Washington Post, paint a stark picture of missteps and failures in the American effort to pacify and rebuild the country.
articles.abstract: The documents, obtained by The Washington Post, paint a stark picture of missteps and failures in the American effort to pacify and rebuild the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prominent American officials concealed pessimistic assessments about the long-running military campaign in Afghanistan, according to thousands of pages of documents published by The Washington Post on Monday. Taken together, the documents paint a stark picture of missteps and failures.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff

articles.headline: Report on F.B.I. Russia Inquiry Finds Serious Errors but Debunks Anti-Trump Plot
articles.snippet: A long-awaited report by the Justice Department’s inspector general delivers a scathing critique of the F.B.I.’s handling of a wiretap application but also punctures many conspiracy theories.
articles.abstract: A long-awaited report by the Justice Department’s inspector general delivers a scathing critique of the F.B.I.’s handling of a wiretap application but also punctures many conspiracy theories.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — F.B.I. officials had sufficient reason to open the investigation into links between Russia and Trump campaign aides in 2016 and acted without political bias, a long-awaited report said on Monday, but it concluded that the inquiry was a rushed and dysfunctional process marked by serious errors in documents related to a wiretap.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage, Adam Goldman and Katie Benner
